title: teen who lost lower leg
story: Exclusive: Teen who lost her lower leg to cancer just wants to make music and you can helpLulu Blundell was forced to embark on brutal chemotherapy before having her lower leg amputated - the courageous young lady, now , who raised £, for the Teenage Cancer Trust, has a Christmas wish through Mirror Christmas Appeal partner Make-A-Wish UKIncredible Lulu has raised £, Image: CollectByClaire OBoyleAssistant Features Editor Writer:,  Dec | commentsMusic fan Lulu Blundell spent her early teens dashing between swimming lessons and rugby matches to live gigs. Then aged , on the day of her first GCSE exam in May , she learned she had Ewing sarcoma, a rare bone cancer. “I remember thinking, I hope they don’t cancel our holiday – because I thought I’d be fine in a few weeks. It was disbelief,” recalls Lulu, now . Mum Carolyn, , says: “Lulu had been complaining of a pain in her lower leg and she was referred for a biopsy.” Treated at Weston Park Hospital, in Sheffield, she embarked on intensive chemotherapy. “It was scary,” says Lulu, whose dad is teacher Stephen, . “Lulu was there five days in a row,  hours a day getting chemo,” says executive head teacher Carolyn. “It was brutal. She’d have five days, then a week off, another five, then a week off, for  months. She is extraordinary.” By Jason Beattie For the majority of families this Christmas will be a joyous time of presents, food and fun. But for some children the festive season will be very dferent. Across the country there are more than , young people who are critically ill. Many will be spending what should be a special time of the year in hospital. Others will have to have treatment, scans or blood tests. With your help we can give them a Christmas that they will always remember. This year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal is raising funds for Make-A-Wish UK that helps seriously ill young people make their dreams come true.It could be they want to meet their hero or heroine or feed an animal at the zoo or travel to see Santa in Lapland. The money raised could help Joshua, six, who has severe epilepsy, achieve his wish of a bedroom makeover or Summer, also six, who has acute leukaemia and dreams of a bouncy castle. Each year Make-A-Wish helps hundreds of critically ill children achieve their letime’s ambition. But to make a wish come true takes an army of volunteers, supporters and donors. That’s why every penny you donate could make a dference. Granting a wish can transform a child’s le. It gives them something to look forward to. For others it provides a special memory which makes the treatment they need more bearable.It can also help their parents who, despite doing everything they can for their sick child, feel it is not enough. Jason Suckley, Make-A-Wish UK chief executive, said: “I met the family of a boy who was recovering from brain surgery. “His grandmother told me how dficult it had been for her to watch her daughter struggle with the challenges of her son’s condition.But while they were enjoying his wish together, her daughter turned to her and said, ‘There is still magic in this world isn’t there mum ’ . “That’s just one instance that illustrates how the power of a wish lies in sharing positive memories with loved ones. “Every donation from Mirror readers will help us create those memories – bringing joy to ill children and their families during the darkest of times.” In October , Lulu had her lower left leg amputated at the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital in Birmingham. “Lulu ended up in high dependency, and six or seven times we thought we might lose her,” says Carolyn. Thankfully, Lulu, whose brother Seth is  months younger, pulled through. “I’d known from when I was diagnosed it was going to be amputated, it was the best option,” Lulu says. Online: www.make-a-wish.org.uk mirror Text: To donate £ text the word LIGHT to . If you’d like to give £ but do not want marketing communications, text LIGHT NO to .You can text more than onceyou wish to donate more. Post: Please post cheques payable to MAKE-A-WISH UK to Freepost address below: Freepost Plus RUCS-LHTL-CJGU Make-A-Wish Mirror Appeal Make-A-Wish UK, Seventh Floor, Thames Tower, Station Road, Reading, Berkshire RG LX Her mum adds: “Three weeks after her amputation she went to a Liam Gallagher gig.” The chemo ended in January . She started an English degree at Newcastle University in September but she still needs scans every  weeks.Lulu, who raised £, for the Teenage Cancer Trust, would love a Fender guitar, through Mirror Christmas Appeal partner Make-A-Wish UK. “I love music so much and played the piano,” she says. “I’d love to have my own guitar for something fun to do.” Her mum adds: “After everything she’s been through, and the bravery she’s shown in helping to raise money, we’d love to make that wish come true.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CancerMirror Christmas appealXmas Appeal Teenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: time admit defeat plan downsized
story: Time to admit defeat and plan downsized Christmas as Covid determined to ruin funWith the new Omicron iant spreading in the UK, Eva Simpson says we should start planning for a scaled down festive seasonCovid could be about to ruin Christmas again this year Image: Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Dec | commentsIt’s beginning to look a lot like a Covid Christmas... again. Don’t say you haven’t been warned.The signs are all here. A new mutant Covid strain. Theof isolation for anyone in contact with someone with said strain, the Omicron iant. And the enforcement of mask wearing on public transport and inside shops.Closer to home, the lovely Christmas carols concert for my son’s primary school, which was due to take place as it has done for many years in a local department store, has been cancelled. The race really is on to save Christmas. The Prime Minister is banking on an ambitious booster jab programme to help and, as usual, there’s talk of calling in the army. Butit’s anything like a year ago, then maybe it’s time to admit the race has already been lost and to start planning to downsize accordingly.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  If the  holiday season taught us anything, it was not to leave things to the last minute, and to appreciate time with our nearest and dearest. So start planning now. And while it’s fun to celebrate Christmas by going out partying and having huge family dinners, Covid seems determined to ruin the fun. But I have to admit there is a lot to be said for keeping things small, simple and just staying indoors. I’ve had quite a few conversations with people who’ve said that as much as they missed their families last year, it was quite nice to stay in their own home and do things their way. No squabbling between the adults and children over what time to have lunch or open presents. People were relieved there was much less pressure and felt they were able to have a good time. There’s just something about Christmas, when it’s not in your own home, that brings out the petulant teenager in all of us. Then there’s the talk of supply shortages meaning there won’t be as many Christmas presents to buy. Again, is that so bad  How many pairs of socks and last-minute bath sets do we really need  As long as we’re safe and at home, isn’t that the best gt any of us can hope to receive  Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ChristmasCoronavirusMutant Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: You can get paid £, to watch Christmas films while you eat delicious snacksBuzz Bingo are looking for looking for a lucky person who will become their official Christmas Film Tester while enjoying a supply of festive snacks such as mince piesYou could be paid a grand to watch Christmas films Image: Getty Images iStockphotoBySimon Duke:,  Dec | commentsIf you love Christmas and also happen to be looking for your dream job the perfect opportunity may have arisen for you. Someone will be able to earn £, just for binge-watching a load of Christmas films while eating snacks,. Buzz Bingo are looking for looking for one festive film fan to become their official Christmas Film Tester watch and rate Christmas films, helping decide once and for all what is the best of all time. The chosen applicant will also be paid to do so. You can star in your festive version of Gogglebox as, as well as being given a grand to watch Christmas movies and youaposll also be treated to an array of edible goodies.  The successful applicant will receive a Christmas hamper to help you get them through the job, filled with tasty treats such as a classic chocolate selection box, hot chocolate, mince pies and more. The films youaposll need to watch and review are:The Santa Clause Miracle on th Street Christmas With The Kranks Bad Santa Tim Burtonaposs The Nightmare Before Christmas Deck The Halls Love Actually Jingle All The Way Elf Home Alone Die Hard How The Grinch Stole Christmas On its website, Buzz Bingo said: With the festive season officially begun, the team at Buzz Bingo are on a mission to set the record straight and determine the best Christmas film of all time. We’re looking for one festive film buff to watch and rate Christmas films, crowning the best of all time. The chosen applicant will also be paid to do so. That’s right, you could be paid an amazing £, to watch all your favourite festive films and crown the winner.  Additionally, you will receive a Christmas hamper to help you get through the job, including festive goodies such as a classic chocolate selection box, hot chocolate, mince pies and more.Applicants need to be  and over and to put yourself forward you need to tell Buzz Bingo why youaposre the perfect candidate for the job.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Christmas" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: children paid almost 3m after
story: Children to be paid almost £m after pregnant mum shot dead by police SHE called forCharleena Lyles, , was shot dead by two police who responded to her call in which she was reporting a burglary - with medical examinations finding she was hit by seven bulletsCharleena Lyles was killed by Seattle police officers on th June  Image: NewsflashByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments Four children are to be paid almost £million after their pregnant mother was shot dead by police who she called to report a burglary.The City of Seattle has agreed to pay . million to the children of Charleena Lyles. The -year-old mum died on th June  after calling police for help.Two officers responded to the call and, according to their report, evidence at the scene pointed towards the fact that the crime had been staged.They described how Charleena took out a kne as she stood in her kitchen. They both shot at her and she received seven bullets and died from her injuries.  She was pregnant at the time and her death sparked outrage and protests. Her sister Monika Williams was reported as saying: Why couldnapost they have Tased her  They could have taken her down. I could have taken her down. The court heard how Charleena was a victim of domestic violence and had a history of suffering with mental health issues. Her children, aged between five and , filed a wrongful death civil lawsuit, which was planned to go to trial in February of next year.  However, on th November, a settlement of USD . millionwas reached after a -and-a-half-hour session overseen by a judge. The children, two of whom have special needs, are now in the care of the victimaposs aunt, who is in the process of adopting them. The Seattle Police Department wrote in an online statement: We hope that this tragic case continues to serve to drive momentum towards comprehensive, holistic reform of all systems that meet at the intersection of public health and public safety. title: woman 52 who been married
story: Woman, , who has been married  times to nine men still looking for the oneMonette, from the US, has explained how her  marriages went off the rails and revealed that she has been proposed to  times in her quest to find a le partnerBack when Monette was new to weddings Image: TLCByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A woman who has been married  times to nine dferent men is hasnapost given up on love and is convinced she will find aposthe oneapos.Monette was always boy crazy and fantasised about marrying her brotheraposs friends when she was a young girl. She first tied the knot as a young woman having just left school. Sheaposd known her first fella in high school and married him two months after telling her sister that heaposd be her groom. It didnapost last between the young lovers, leading Monette, , to betroth a man who she had always had a lot of fun with.  Sadly that union also fell apart, only for them to give it another go shortly after they officially split. Similar problems crept into their marriage once more, leading Monette to put a ring on another man. However, as much as she loved his kids, the pair proved not to be a forever couple.“Number five was probably one of the loves of my le,” she said on T LC ’s Addicted to Marriage.“Husband number six just seemed so nice and kind so I married him and then I married him again.”  While some people may have hung up their wedding shows after number seven, Monette is not one to be deterred. She said: “Number eight, I met him online and then one week later we drove to Vegas and got married. “Number nine was a very charismatic guy and just the kind of guy that you shouldn’t be attracted to but sometimes you are. “Number ten I knew in elementary school he’s a very good person but we should have just stayed friends.  “Number , I’m not even going there with that one, there’s nothing to say!” Remarkably, Monette had plenty more opportunities to get married than she ended up taking. Over the course of her le she has been proposed to  times. Despite such a large amount of heartbreak and more proposals than an investorsapos conference, Monette is far from jaded. “Not one time did I go into a marriage thinking it would end in orce every single time I was like ‘please let this be the one’,” she said.  “My whole le I’ve spent trying to force these men to live up to this elusive soulmate I have in my head. “Now I don’t need to look for that any more.” Monette has now been dating -year-old John for over two years, and he has been married himself twice before. He said: “We met online and I told Monette after three dates that I loved her, I believe in expressing myself and I felt that way.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveMarriage" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside eerie abandoned yorkshire farm
story: Inside eerie abandoned Yorkshire farm still full of antiques and ‘creepy’ toysUrban explorer Daniel Sims stumbled across a farm and found it was filled with old furniture, china crockery and antique ornaments – as well as vintage children’s toysDaniel heard about the abandoned farm from another urban explorer Image: Jam Press Vid BeardedRealityByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments An eerie abandoned farm in Yorkshire was recently uncovered by an urban explorer from Huddersfield.Daniel Sims, , stumbled across the farm after hearing about it from another explorer and found “everything left behind” inside the building - including toothbrushes, beauty products, and furniture. The urban explorer posted a video about his findings on his YouTube channel, BeardedReality, where he showcased the ious rooms that were still packed with clutter, the Daily Mail reports. In the living room, a newspaper from  was still present alongside several large paintings, an antique cabinet, and an old Philips stereo system. While the kitchen looked as though it had been ransacked, with the kettle and assorted crockery and appliances left strewn about the room.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Daniel said: “I started seeing lots of items left around so a wave of excitement took hold as I went inside. “I could tell it was going to be interesting to look at this place. “The atmosphere was calm at first, however at times it became quite eerie – we would hear random noises throughout the house that put us a little on edge.”  The explorer guessed the property had been abandoned for only a couple of years, although they found old-fashioned televisions and dated furnishings throughout the home. And among the creepiest items left behind at the property was an array of bizarre children’s toys that looked as though they had come straight from a horror film. One wooden doll could be seen laying in a cot and had bright blue eyes that were much cleaner than the rest of her face.  While another doll made of porcelain was found in one of the upstairs bedrooms and had been persevered in its box. Daniel also found antique items including stacks of china crockery and ornaments and an entire shelf filled with bottles of wine. In his video, he exclaimed: “Thereaposs got to be thousands of pounds worth of stuff here.” What’s more, the explorer found a vintage Melotte hand-cranked cream separator, which was used in the dairy industry in the th century.  Daniel explored the property with his friend Steve, and the pair were “blown away” by everything they saw. He said: “The main area that caught my surprise was in the basement where the majority of the collectables were squirrelled away and other random antiques. “To the right people and collectors some of these inidual items could be worth hundreds. “We were left wondering why such a place had become like this – we were blown away by everything we saw.” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: lush assistant too stunned speak
story: Lush assistant too stunned to speak as woman mistakes soap for foodJackie was out shopping with her pal in Lush when she spotted a free sample counter filled with what she assumed was food - thankfully the funny moment was caught on camera and shared on TikTok Image: @jackiegansky TiktokByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Dec | commentsA video of a sales assistantaposs hilarious reaction to a woman mistaking a piece of soap for food has gone viral. The woman, Jackie, was browsing in Lush with her pal when she set her sights on what she thought was a free sample of food to try. Eager to give it a taste, she popped it in her mouth and began to chew it. But as she did so, the retail assistant spotted her and was in complete shock at what he had seen. He then started laughing, before telling the customer that what she’d just eaten was actually a piece of soap, not food.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.Jackie shared the video on her TikTok @jackiegansky, where it has racked up more than . million views at the time of writing, and , comments from people in hysterics.One person said: THE MAN WAS TOO STUNNED TO SPEAK. Another wrote: She even chewed it immediately. Why would a soap store have anything other than SOAP samples  LMAOOOO, exclaimed a third. Someone  put: aposNo no no itaposs soapapos got me farting on the floor HAHHAAHAH. The clip was also later shared on a Reddit thread full of funny fails, where users shared stories of their own. “At a wedding one time, a guy at our table thought the flower-looking butter was white chocolate so he popped one in his mouth. Everyone stopped talking and just looked at him, he decided to roll with it and eat it but wasn’t thrilled,” said one person. Another admitted: “I was at a restaurant with my partner and dog. They brought the bill with two cookies. I, a lover of desserts, immediately pop one in my mouth while the waiter yells in exasperation ‘they’re not for humans! They were treats for my dog.” While a third commented: “I had this same look once…was at a hibachi grill with a friend. I told them the big glob was wasabi and do not eat it by itself…to add it to the food in small amounts. I look over after just taking a bit to see my friend eating the whole thing of wasabi. Lol He did not have a good time afterwards.”Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: parents giving away 200k home
story: Parents giving away £k home for just £ to lucky winner for incredible reasonMy we and I want to help disabled children experience as much joy as our little girl - thats why were raffling off our family home, writes Adam ThwaitesSomething about the idea made us fall in love with it Image: Adam ThwaitesopinionByAdam Thwaites:,  Dec | commentsWe werenapost sure what reaction weaposd get when we announced we were raffling off our family home for £ - but our friends and family - even strangers - have been hugely supportive.My we Liz and I have been thinking of selling our home for a while as we want to move closer to family, work and our daughter Emilyaposs nursery, and weaposve always felt a little pull whenever we see other property competitions. Something about the idea made us fall in love with it.Whataposs more, there have been loads of people using the opportunity to raise money for charities that meant something to them. Liz works at Grace House, a charity providing short breaks for disabled children, and I was talking to the Registered Manager one day about their need for a wheelchair-accessible swing.What do you think of Adam and Lizaposs gesture  Let us know in the comments below Emily loves the swings in the park so much, it made me feel sad that not everyone has the opportunity to have a go on them. After a bit of googling we saw these swings cost around £,. I put two and two together, and Liz and I decided that we should go for it and try to raffle off our home, enabling us to move, letting someone win an amazing prize in time for Christmas, and also raising funds for Grace House. The charity aims to enrich the lives of disabled children, young people, and their families in the local area by offering short breaks for disabled children, counselling, family activities, youth groups, and much more. Itaposs very close to our hearts.  Our beautul house in South Tyneside has three bedrooms, two storeys and a garden. Itaposs close to a big park and only eight minutes drive from the nearest beach. And you wonapost have to pay any property transport fees as thataposll all be done for you. If we sell all , raffle tickets, one lucky winner will be waking up on Christmas Day with the deeds to our house. And Grace House will be getting a £, donation for that special swing. I asked Liz for her input into this piece and she laughed: Itaposs a crazy idea to put your home up for raffle instead of just selling it the conventional way but Adam convinced me it would be a good idea. It was very important to us that we did something special with the extra money we could raise. Working in Grace House I see where the money goes and having that extra cash means we can do more for the kids and young people we have.  A wheelchair-accessible swing has been on our wish list for a while but because itaposs so expensive itaposs never been achievable but this time we could really try and get it for the kids. So what would you doyou won our house for £  Live mortgage- and rent-free  Rent it out for extra income  Sell it - or maybe be inspired by us and give it to charity  Thereaposs only one way to find out, isnapost there... To take part in Adam and Lizaposs raffle, go to Raffall for the TCs. title: woman red faced after accidentally
story: Woman red-faced after accidentally wearing builder’s hoodie for a week – not boyfriend’sComedian Fern Brady was left horried when she realised the comfy hoodie she’d been wearing for a week wasn’t her boyfriend’s – but was actually their builder’sThe woman threw on the hoodie thinking it belonged to her boyfriendImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Dec | commentsFor many women in relationships, throwing on your partner’s clothes brings a level of comfort you can’t quite explain. But whatthe hoodie you pick up doesn’t actually belong to your partner and you instead accidentally start wearing a stranger’s clothes  That’s what happened to comedian Fern Brady, who says she spent a whole week wearing a hoodie that she thought belonged to her boyfriend - but was actually her builder’s. Posting on Twitter under the username @FernBrady, Fern detailed how she “realised with horror” that she’d been walking around her house in her builder’s hoodie while the builder had been working on her home.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. She wrote: “Iaposve been wearing my boyfriendaposs hoodie around the house for the last week. I tried to give it back last night. He said ‘Thataposs not my hoodie.’ Realised with horror Iaposve been wearing our builderaposs hoodie. In front of the builder.” Fern, , said she’d even fallen asleep in the cosy jumper and had greeted the builder when she woke up – still wearing his clothes. She added: “I had a little sleep in it at one point. Came out my room. Said good morning to the builder. Wearing his clothes.”  The woman was so embarrassed by her blunder she couldn’t bring herself to face the builder, so just threw the hoodie into the room he was working in – but he moved it back into the living room. She wrote: “After realising my mistake after a week, I threw his hoodie into the room heaposs been working in. He put it in our living room. What does it mean  Am I going out with the builder now  Heaposs pretty old.” Fern’s tweets received hundreds of replies, and many people were inspired to share their own embarrassing stories. One person wrote: “My husband was away with work. Came home late one night and left very early next morning having rearranged kids bath foam letters to say, ‘fancy a shag’. “Not sure who was most mortied - me or the bathroom fitters that had been working there all week.” While another said: “I remember being  and leaving my jumper at my friends. I then saw her dad wearing it and could never ask for it back.” And a third revealed: “After years of filching my elder sonaposs assorted sports tops, we realised recently that one that I thought was his, isnapost. Nor is it mine. Whose is it and how do I come to have it  Nobody knows.” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news world-news meet-lonely-princess-set-become-"Emperor Akihito thanks Japanese in farewell and prays for peaceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsShe’s the little-known princess who appeared to have a lonely childhood blighted by school bullying and health problems.But today Princess Aiko of Japan, daughter of Emperor Nahurito, celebrates her th birthday - and it will mark her entrance into official public le, where she will carry out royal duties.On Sunday, she will enter the world stage in an official ceremony to mark her coming-of-age, where she will be expected to wear formal dress and even a tiara. And she’s already pledged her service to her country. In a statement released by the Imperial Household Agency to mark her birthday, she said: “I would like to refine myself and move forward step by step so that I can grow into an adult who can be of service to others.”  But who exactly is Princess Aiko and what will her future hold  We take a look… Only child Princess Aiko, also known as Princess Toshi, is the only child of Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako.She was born at Tokyoaposs Imperial Palace in  and her parents broke with tradition by choosing her name rather than leaving it to her grandfather, former Emperor Akihito.Aiko is her personal name, while her imperial title Toshi means a person who respects others. School struggles Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.When she was just eight years old, Aiko refused to go to school because she said she was the victim of bullying.She was eventually persuaded toto the classroom but onlyher mother could go too. It was some time before she felt confident to go to school on her own. Aiko’s parents tried to make her school days more bearable by regularly inviting her classmates to the palace. An investigation revealed that she had suffered “violent things” from boys in another class. The school, however, explained away the incident, claiming that two boys accidentally collided with her, “which scared her”. Health problems  In October , there were more worries about the princess when she missed nearly two months from school due to an unspecied illness. Palace officials confirmed the teenager had been complaining of stomach problems and dizziness, which they attributed to studying for exams as well as practising for an athletics event. She later attended Gakushuin Girls’ Senior High School, where the princess was able to spend three months studying at Eton in Britain, staying in a boarding house. Aiko then started accompanying her parents on royal duties after her father ascended to the Chrysanthemum Throne in . She is currently enrolled at Gakushuin University, where she has been attending online classes due to the Covid pandemic.According to the Japan Times, she studies Japanese literature, English and Spanish as well as Japanese history and traditional art.In September, she moved from the Akasaka Imperial Residence to the Imperial Palace with her parents taking her dog Yuri and cats Mii and Seven with her. Entering royal le  Now she has turned , Aiko will be formally welcomed into public le in a ceremony set to take place on Sunday. While dressed in formal attire, she will visit sanctuaries where the Imperial Familyaposs ancestors are buried and offer prayers to the gods, as well as be greeted by her parents and grandparents. Part of her formal attire will be a tiara, however itaposs been reported that the one she will wear for the ceremony will be a second-hand one - and not made especially for her. The tiara she will wear was first made for her aunt Princess Sayako but it is thought that the piece is being adjusted so it fits her perfectly on her big day. Itaposs said that there was some surprise in Japan, when it was announced that no new tiara was being made for the occasion. Future le  Once her official coming-of-age ceremony is out of the way, it is believed Aikoaposs first public appearance will be on New Yearaposs Day, when members of Japanaposs Imperial Family meet with well-wishers at Tokyoaposs Imperial Palace. She will also continue her university studies and in March will appear at a traditional coming-of-age news conference. However, depending on how Aikoaposs adult le pans out, her time in Japanaposs Imperial Family could be short.Thataposs becausea female member of the Imperial Family marries a commoner, she will lose her royal status and even her title.Earlier this year, her cousin Princess Mako was forced to relinquish her title when she married her commoner long-term love Kei Komuro.Before Makoaposs wedding, there were emotional scenes when she was forced to say goodbye to her parents and younger sister Kako at the entrance to their home.Though all wore masks in line with Japanaposs coronavirus protocol, her mother could be seen blinking rapidly, asto fight off tears.Mako bowed formally to her parents but her sister grabbed her shoulders and the two shared a long embrace. Chrysanthemum Throne  Of course, Aiko may choose not to marry - but despite being the only child of the Emperor, she will not ascend to the throne because women are not allowed to rule over Japan. In Japan there are just three heirs to the throne, Emperor Naruhito’s younger brother Crown Prince Akishino, , his son Prince Hisahito, , and the emperor’s uncle Prince Hitachi, . Experts have warned the royal line could completely vanishthe Imperial House Law is not revised. In , an expert  called for a revision to the law to allow the imperial couple’s first born, regardless of gender, to ascend the throne. But this was halted with the birth of Prince Hisahito in  - the was the first male member of the Imperial Family born in nearly  years. There are also fears that banning women from marrying outside the nobility, effectively forcing them to leave the Royal Familythey chose to wed, means the busy schedule of official duties is falling onto fewer and fewer people. Relaxing the rules is popular in Japan, with  per cent of people said to be supportive of allowing women to become emperors, not least because it would keep the monarchy relevant in an ever-changing world. But Japan’s former prime minister Shinzo Abe was reportedly against allowing women to rule, believing that because the throne has consistently been passed down through the male line, it should continue the same way. news world-news panicked-surfers-rush-shore-massive-"Puerto Rico: Surfer flees to land after being chased by sharkByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Surfers frantically paddled back to shore with a shark nipping at their heels.Heart-stopping footage shows the moment wave riders were confronted with the aquatic beast. As choppy swell swirled around the surfers, the sharkaposs impressive dorsal fin can be seen breaching the wateraposs surface. It seems like man and marine monster are just feet away from one another off Middles Beach, Isabela, in Puerto Rico. Surfer Rolando Montes can be seen making a panicked bid to paddle back to the safety of the beach while his pal also tries to get away on top of his board. Stunned onlooker Jorge Benitez filmed the encounter and watched as his friends fled.  This is the first shark I see, Benitez said. Although itaposs known they are around the areas, but apparently they have enough food so we barely have incidentsany. Shark attacks in waters off Puerto Rico are rare, with the most recent incident a decade ago. Over the past nine years nearly  people have been mauled across the globe. The current hotspot is the US, where  shark bites were reported this year, compared to  in Australia. This year  shark attacks - six being fatal - have been reported across the globe. As scary as sharks may seem, the odds of dying in their jaws is very low compared to dozens of other causes. According to the World Health Organisation, ischaemic heart disease is the biggest killer and claimed . million lives in  - compared to  shark deaths that year. That means youaposre , times more likely to die due to narrowed heart arteries than in a set of ferocious aquatic gnashers. Regardless, shark attacks remain more interesting than chronic diseases in most peopleaposs eyes. Recently a huge great white shark attacked a film crewaposs boat after they tried attaching a camera to one of the predatoraposs fins. The Discovery Channel camera crew were on location off Stewart Island in New Zealand when the shark burst out of the water and tried to sink its razor teeth into their dinghy. Before the attack the film crew tried to latch a camera to a fin in the hopes of seeing the apex predatoraposs feeding ground. Within moments the shark darted at the vessel and rushed up out of the water and bit down on a rope attaching them to a larger vessel. The narrator can be heard warning of the dangersthe crew are separated from the main ship. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: springfield swoops for north rival tulloch in 56 4m housebuilding deal
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: review gary barlow aberdeen
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: bubble tea north east
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. title: relief as replacement abbeyton bridge finally confirmed three years after demolition
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
