title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: battling star hold title favourites
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Red Star ed home with a point after a battling performance against league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie on Saturday November .Star stung the hosts at Cowan Park, Barrhead, with an excellent start to the match, forcing a succession of corners before the ever-dangerous Coll McCallum finished after an excellent delivery by Craig Aitken.The visitors doubled their lead after  minutes when Craig Aitken broke clear down the left and finished with an excellent effort into the goalkeeper’s far corner to put Star - ahead.Star were under pressure for much of the remainder of the half but always carried a threat on the break, with Stuart MacLean’s pace causing the home side no end of problems.Into the second half, Arthurlie forced their way back into the match and pulled a goal back after a rare defensive lapse by Star on  minutes. Star failed to clear the danger from a cross and the unfortunate Coll McCallum erted into his own net past Leon Murphy.The Arthurlie equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when winger Sean Ross cut inside before unleashing a spectacular effort into the top corner.The hosts would have been expected to go on and win the game from here but the Star defence remained well-organised and resolute and a fine goalkeeping performance from Leon Murphy ensured the Lochgilphead side ed home with a well-earned point.Star put their unbeaten league record on the line on Saturday November  when they welcome fellow Argyll side Cardross to the Joint Campus G. Kick-off pm.PIC:The SAFL Division One table after last weekend#s matches. no_aStar_LeagueTable

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 19 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: christmas cakes and crafts for seniors
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA fantastic turnout of people enjoyed Inveraray Senior Citizens Club#s Christmas Fayre.Held on Saturday November , there was a tombola along with Christmas crafts and gts, jams and chutneys and home baking which were snapped up in no time as always.The club would like to thank everyone for their donations, support and for going along.Their generosity was outstanding and funds raised will go a long way to help running the Inveraray Senior Citizens Club and the upkeep of the Nicoll Hall.In a new move for Inveraray Senior Citizens Club, it now has its own Facebook page.

title: galas-chance-put-town-football-map
story: ARGUABLY Gala Fairydean Roversrsquo biggest game of the season takes place on Saturday when League Two Annan Athletic visit Netherdale in the third round of the Scottish Cup.The winners will go into Monday nightrsquos draw along with the giants of Scottish football ndash and potentially a huge pay day could be the reward.Manager Neil Hastings is not underestimating the challenge ahead and is urging fans to create a good atmosphere and cheer the team onto victory.He told the Border : ldquoSaturday will be a huge challenge against a team who perform at a higher level."Itrsquos the biggest competition we play in, and we have the chance to reach the fourth round. Crowds have been improving recently and Irsquom hoping to see the local community turn out in their numbers for this chance to put the town on the football map. I know the players will relish a good atmosphere.The pair met last Boxing Day in the same competition and the visitors took the honours with a late goal and Hastings knows the task ahead.Hastings added: ldquoAs a manager I never stop thinking about the next game but Irsquove seen Annan a few times and had reports. I know it will be dficult as they have some good inidual players. We played them last year and since then they have added quality and depth to their squad. Theyrsquove been playing well and will be looking to get into the play-offs for promotion and are well-placed.Tickets cost pound  pound ndash pay at the gate. Us pound.

title: see-live-rugby-region-weekend
story: A FULL-CARD of live rugby s to the region and beyond this weekend.On Saturdayin the Premiership Hawick host GHA, Selkirk are away at Musselburgh whilst Jed-Forest are at home to Edinburgh Accies.In the Tennents National League Division One Gala travel to Stirling to face the Wolves, Kelso host Cartha Queenrsquos Park at Poynder Park whilst Melrose are in the capital to face Heriotrsquos Blues.In the Tennents National League Division Two Peebles are away at Whitecraigs.In the Tennents National League Division Three Berwick are away to Greenock Wanderers.In East League One Duns are away to Linlithgow.In East League Two Hawick Linden face Corstorphine in Edinburgh.In East league Three Gala YM host Earlston in a Borders derby.In the Reserve East One Hawick Force host Biggar, Jed-Forest A are at home to Edinburgh accies and Selkirk A are away to Musselburgh A.In the Reserve League East Two, Gala A host Leith A, Melrose Storm are at home to Edinburgh Accies B, Peebles Reds host Watsonians B and Kelso Sharks are away to Linlithgow A,In the Semi-Junior Borders League Hawick Youth host Gala Wanderers, Kelso Harlequins are at home to Carlisle Colts, Melrose Wasps hosts Morpeth Colts and Peebles Colts are at home to Alnwick.On Sunday Kelso Ladies play Stewartry at Poynder Park.As always games are subject to late change so always check before going along.

title: mccallum-hoping-world-title-eliminator-vegas
story: Galashiels boxer John McCallumrsquos IBF Intercontinental Cruiserweight title fight against Kazakhstan fighter Issa Akberbayev at York Hall was postponed at the last minute.The fight had been scheduled for Friday  November but Akberbayev withdrew citing illness two days before.A previous fight between the pair was called off by Akberbayev due to Covid.A frantic search to find another opponent for the McCallum failed and he is now in talks about a world title eliminator in Las Vegas next month.A disappointed McCallum told the Border : ldquoThat fight was for meant to be for my dad Steven Robinson who is seriously ill with cancer in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital and that has been taken away.ldquoI had a massive support and many of them were spending the weekend in London.ldquoIrsquom really annoyed and it has even made me think of chucking it. The whole thing has been a massive disappointment. It wasnrsquot about belts or money it was for my dad and as soon as I found out I drove to Edinburgh to be with him.ldquoI donrsquot think Irsquoll be fighting Akberbayev again after the two call offs. This was an oral virus which meant he was unable to fly.ldquoIrsquove been asked to fight Andrew Tabiti who is in the Mayweather camp for a world title eliminator which would take place in Las Vegas on -December at the Mandalay Bay and Irsquom up for that. The Intercontinental belt is still vacant butthis comes off Irsquoll bypass that.ldquoI peaked for the Akberbayev so Irsquoll have a few days rest then get back in training at my local gym before heading to Vegas about five days before the fight. Irsquom in good shape so that should be OK.

title: date-announced-next-years-maroond-gala-festival
story: BUILDING on its success in , the Maroonrsquod@Gala sports and music festival willto Netherdale next year.The event will take place at the home of Gala Rugby, on Saturday, August , .Praised for its innovation and inclusivity, the inaugural edition of Maroonrsquod@Gala provided competition opportunities for primary school age rugby players under s under s under s senior and ladies sections and players with physical and learning disabilities.It also played host to football and running events.In addition to the showpiece sporting event ndash which culminated with the final of the famous Gala Sevens - there were live bands, street food, themed drinks areas and fun zones.Despite challenging weather conditions and the requirement to work in accordance with government coronavirus guidance, the free  event was attended by around ,-, people.It received positive feedback with participants, vendors and spectators stating their intention tofor future editions.Ian Dalgleish, the president of Gala RFC, said: ldquoThe Maroonrsquod@Gala concept has been very well received and the success of our inaugural event this summer, coupled with positive feedback and the continued support of our partners, has given us confidence to bring it back in .ldquoTogether, wersquore committed to creating a community event that local people want to be part of and to celebrate the proud sporting history of Gala Rugby, as well as to inspire our future stars."We also want to build on what we achieved this year and to extend the feel-good factor beyond the Netherdale site, maximising the positive economic impact in Galashiels town centre.Maroonrsquod@Gala was initially scheduled to take place in April  but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Further details will be announced in due course.

title: peebles-man-runs-marathon-memory-late-father
story: PEEBLES man Steve Murray along with three of his friends has raised pound,. for the Alec Lucas Memorial Trust, by running a marathon around the town.The four men decided to undertake the challenge on October , despite the heavy rain, as that day marked the th anniversary of the unexpected and tragic death of Steversquos father, Steve lsquoScousersquo Murray at the age of .Steve told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoMy dad was my hero, and I canrsquot put into words how dficult his passing has been for me. I still think about him every day and get upset thinking about the things hersquos missed out on being a part of. Coming up to this particular anniversary, I knew I wanted to do something to commemorate his le and to make him proud.The Murrayrsquos moved to the Borders  years ago and were neighbours of the Lucas family so the decision to make the Alec Lucas Memorial Trust their chosen charity was an easy one.The Trust was started by in memory of the -year-old Royal Marine Commando who was killed in action in Kajaki, Afghanistan on November ,  and has raised thousands of pounds for charity.Steve continued: ldquoThe Lucas family were our neighbours in Whitehaugh#Park, I have#known them since moving to Peebles from Liverpool in .##Alec was our first babysitter, and wersquod have him playing football in the garden for hours. Dad#was very fond#of Alec, having gotten to know him better through#drinking in the#Crown, and I know he would be fully behind#this choice of charity.#ldquoWhen I first started drinking in the pubs, Alec always made a point of coming over for a chat, checking I was alright, and buying me a bevy. He didnrsquot have to do that, but it was reassuring to know you had an ally in the pub when you didnrsquot know many people. Raising money for his charity is an honour.ldquoInitially we hoped to raise pound, and didnrsquot expect to raise over pound,.Alecs father Adrian added: "On behalf of the Fund Id like to offer huge congratulations to Steve, Richard, Finlay and Duncan for a fantastic effort. The money raised will go to the Royal Marines charities to support serving and retired Royal Marines, of which Alec was a proud member.".removeThe other runners were Richard Harragan, Finlay Moffat and Duncan McPherson.Anyone wishing to donate can do so at https:uk.virginmoneygiving StephenMurray before November .

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: jedburgh-man-drove-almost-three-times-alcohol-limit
story: A -YEAR-OLD man who admitted driving while almost three times the alcohol limit has been banned from the road for  months at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Owen Campbell, who gave an address in Jedburgh, was involved in an accident at Hunterrsquos Bridge, Kelso, on December  last year.He had an alcohol blood reading of  millilitres, the legal limit being .The court heard Campbell had to be cut free from the wreckage and was taken to hospital where the blood test was taken.He was fined pound and told he could part in the Drink Drivers Rehabilitation Scheme whichcompleted successfully at his own expense would reduce theof the ban by  per cent.

title: garvald-west-linton-new-building-only-way-meet-clients-needs
story: A BORDERS care provider says a new accommodation block is the ldquoonly way it can meet the needs of its clients.Plans for the ldquopurpose-built structure on the Garvald House estate, West Linton, have been submitted to Scottish Borders Council.Garvald West Linton provides residential accommodation for adults with learning dficulties across a mix of modern and listed buildings.And the charity is now proposing to develop a new detached residential building for six residents.A report attached to the application states that: ldquoThe needs of the client group have changed over recent years. We now have clients with more complex needs.ldquoWhat is meant by complex needs is that alongside a cognitive impairment there are also underlying medical conditions.ldquoThe age profile of our client is also increasing with over half of the client group now in their s.It adds: ldquoWe need to improve our accommodation to manage this ever-increasing level of need. Much of the accommodation is over two levels and, for those with mobility issues, we need to have level access accommodation.ldquoWe also need to provide improved levels of privacy leading to the creation of en-suite facilities for each client.ldquoIt has come into sharp focus that some of the current buildings do not meet modern standards of infection control. Examples would be the lack of staff changing facilities and the number of clients sharing toilet facilities.ldquoWe anticipate that this will be a regulatory requirement in the near future.ldquoThe increased level of need has seen the requirement for increased attendance space and storage of mobility equipment.Garvald West Linton currently provides care to  people with learning disabilities.The proposed site is located away from Garvald House so as to not adversely affect the ldquosetting, character and appearance of the B-listed building.The ground levels will need to be adjusted to accommodate the development, according to the report, giving an opportunity to ldquotuck the new building into the landscape..removeIf approved, each resident will have their own flat with an en-suite bedroom, living room and kitchen.A shared living dining room, accessible bathroom, multi-use space, kitchen, laundry, storage space and plant room will also be provided.A managerrsquos office and staff accommodation are included in the plans.

title: borders-railway-services-suspended-due-power-supply-issues
story: SERVICES on the Borders Railway have been suspended this morning .The announcement was made by Network Rail Scotland, which says the decision is due to power supply issues in the region.A spokesperson said: ldquoWith ongoing power supply issues in the Scottish Borders due to Storm Arwen, we need to suspend services on the Borders Railway this morning to prevent trains from being stranded. Were working with our ScotRail colleagues in our Integrated control room to do this now.

title: borderers-without-power-urged-find-alternative-accommodation
story: BORDERERS who are still without power are being urged to find ldquoalternative accommodation for tonight.Scottish Borders Council says around , have been affected.And it says many could face another night without power.A spokesperson said: ldquoFollowing conversations with Scottish Power Energy Networks it is apparent that the majority of the , homes currently without power will not have supplies restored until tonight at the earliest.ldquoMany homes could face yet another night without power.ldquoWith a further cold night expected, we are therefore urging those currently without power to find alternative accommodation, for example with friends or family, due to the uncertainty regarding the timing of supplies being restored.ldquoAnyone with welfare concerns or unable to find alternative accommodation should call the out of hours emergency number   so that appropriate assistance can be provided by the council or partners.ldquoResilient Community groups have been contacted and asked to assist wherever possible, however, in these exceptional circumstanceswe also askthat people check on vulnerable neighbours.ldquoGiven the ongoing situation and uncertainty regarding the duration of the current incident we areputting in place arrangements to mobilise further support for affected communities.

title: christmas-classic-coming-borders-next-month
story: FOLKSY Theatre are heading back to the Borders, bringing the classic story of The Little Match Girl to le in this brand new, musical adaptation.An upbeat, festive adaptation of the Christmas Classic. The Little Match Girl wanders the street on Christmas Eve, trying to sell her match sticks. Everyone is busy celebrating with fires, Christmas trees and delicious food but outside the girl is cold, sad and alone, that is until she lights one of her matches to keep warm and visions come to le before her very eyes!Join the Little Match Girl on a magical journey, filled with live music, puppetry and multimedia. This is a family Christmas show not to be missed!This production uses a mix of live performers, puppetry, live music and multimedia and brings and happy twist to this much-loved text. With high-energy performances, audience interaction and out right silliness, Folksyrsquos The Little Match Girl will be a theatre experience to be remembered.Tom Hardwicke - Director said: lsquoWe had a lot of fun adapting this beautul tale. It was important to us that we kept the message and morals of the story, whilst making it happier and more uplting. It has been a joy to bring it to le, with our talented actor musicians. Itrsquos a really fun, family show and wersquore delighted to be back working with Live Borders this ChristmasrsquoJason Moyes ndash Senior Creative Programming Officer at Live Borders said: lsquoFolkyrsquos Theatre delight audiences wherever they go, and itrsquos a pleasure to have them performing at the Corn Exchange. The way they work with puppets is quite spectacular and the cast really bring stories to le, itrsquos a perfect show for the whole family.rsquoAimed at children aged - but suitable for all ages. Date: Friday  December  Venue: Corn Exchange, Melrose Doors: : Performance: : Price: pound Duration: hr

title: nicola-sturgeon-speaking-today---next-covid-announcement
story: Nicola Sturgeon is to give an unscheduled Covid briefing today after the first cases of the Omicron iant weredetected in Scotland.The new mutation of Covid, which was first discovered in South Africa, has led to countries around the world altering their rules to try and limit spread of the iant.The first ministers briefing comes after the Omicron iant was identied in Scotland.Speaking yesterday on The Andrew Marr Show, the first minister warned that tigher restrictions may need to be introduced to deal with the new iant, which scientists have warned could be more transmissible than Delta.She said: "I think we may have to go further on restrictingtravelin the days to come."I hope I am wrong about that, but we must keep our minds open to that."Heres what you need to know about todays briefing...What time will Nicola Sturgeons Covid briefing take place today The first minister will give a Covid briefing at :am today.She will be joined by Chief Medical Officer Gregor Smith to discuss the Omicron iant and what they know so far.How can I watch Nicola Sturgeons Covid briefing The Covid briefing is expected to be available to watch on the usual s, including the Scottish governments social media pages.It should also be live tweeted from the SNPs Twitter.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today---omicron-variant-new-rules-considered
story: Nicola Sturgeon held an emergency Covid briefing today as the first cases of the Omicron iant were identied in Scotland.The first minister was joined by Scotlands chief medical officer Dr Gregor Smith to detail what they currently know about the situation in Scotland.The new Omicron iant, which was first discovered in South Africa, has led to countries around the world tightening restrictions amid concerns it could be more transmissible than the Delta iant.UK prime minister Boris Johnson announced tighter measures on mask wearing and travel over the weekend for England, reintroducing mandatory face coveringsin shops and on public transport.Meanwhile, in Scotland, face coverings have been compulsory in these settings throughout the majority of the pandemic as highlighted yesterday by the first minister on the Andrew Marr Show.As the Omicron iant continues to dominate headlines, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today....  Omicron cases detected so far in ScotlandSome of the  cases currently detected have no link to travel to or from South Africa, which suggests there could be some level to community transmission.. "Signicantly" increase compliance with current rulesThe Scottish government is asking people to signicantly increase compliance with the current rules in place: wearing face coverings, taking regular lateral flow tests, getting vaccinated and maintaining high levels of hygiene.. No evidence currently to suggest disease caused by Omicron is more severeAccording to the WHO, there is currently no evidence to suggest that illness caused by the Omicron iant is more severe.However, the first minister said this remained under review. Situation in Scotland stableAlthough the first minister couldnt provide a detailed updated on the figures in Scotland, which will be published later today, she confirmed that the current situation in Scotland was stable..remove. Travel restrictions could be tightenedNicola Sturgeon has written a joint letter with Welsh leader Mark Drakeford to the UK government urging a four nations policy to introduce an -day self-isolation period for people arriving from overseas.The first minister said:"We are proposing a tougher four-nations approach to travel restrictions at this stage that would see people arriving in the UK from overseas asked to self-isolate for eight days. In our proposal, they would take a PCR test on day eight of their arrival, as well as on day ."Currently  countries are on the red list andanyone arriving in Scotland from anywhere outside the common travel area, will be asked to take a PCR Covid test on the second day of their arrival, and self-isolate until they get the result of that test back.. Further actions will be considered in coming daysFurther actions regarding rules and regulations to curb the spread of Covid will be considered in the coming days as we learn more about the Omicron iant. Hope remains that concern surrounding this iant can be reduced as we learn moreThe first minister said that she remained hopeful that as we learn more about this Covid iant, concern surrounding it will reduce rather than increase.

title: borders-drop-in-centres-offer-hot-food-without-power
story: DROP-IN centres will open across the Borders for residents without power in need of hot food, it has been announced.Scottish Borders Councilsays around , homes in the region have been affectedafter Storm Arwen hit the UK over the weekend.And now the council is opening centres at ldquokey locations to provide free soup, meals and hot drinks.The drop-in centres will run at:Duns Primary School ndash am to .pmSt Ronanrsquos Primary School, Innerleithen ndash .am to pmHawick High School ndash .am to pmEarlston Primary School ndash .am to pmAnyone who is unable to travel to the schools should call   to request assistance.An SBC spokesperson said: ldquoThousands of homes have remained without power overnight, mainly across rural Berwickshire, and the council continues to liaise closely with Scottish Power Energy Networks and other key partners across the region to ensure support is available to those affected.ldquoAnyone with welfare concerns or who has been unable to find alternative accommodation should call   so that appropriate assistance can be provided by the Council or partners.ldquoResilient Community groups have continued to support the councilrsquos response, including through providing rolling checks on vulnerable residents in communities affected by power outages.ldquoPlease note that only Scottish Power Energy Networks can provide updates on when power may be restored.

title: local-man-named-community-path-volunteer-year
story: A BORDERS man has been recognised for his dedication to developing and maintaining walking paths in Earlston, contributing to improving the health of many in his local community.Ian Gibb, who co-founded the Earlston Paths Group was named winner of Community Path Volunteer of the Year at Paths for Allrsquos Volunteer Awards  at a virtual awards ceremony hosted by BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Fiona Stalker.Since retiring from Royal Mail in , he has been working to develop and then keep the path routes in Earlston in top form ensuring they are accessible for locals and visitors to enjoy.He said: ldquoI have always enjoyed walking and when I retired it was important that I kept myself busy. Thatrsquos why in , I decided to form the group along with my co-founder Jack, who is sadly no longer with us, to develop existing and new walking routes in the area.ldquoThere is plenty of banter when we go out to work on the paths and it gives us a chance to meet new people like contractors, the Paths for All team, local walkers and people visiting the area itrsquos great to build new relationships with these people and hear their story.ldquoThe group is made up of ten volunteers, each contributing in their own way. As well as that, when we have larger projects on the go we are fortunate that more people in the community come out and help.ldquoThe community has really taken ownership of the paths too,anything happens like broken steps, handrails, bridges or even a fallen tree, they know Irsquom the one to call.The charity supports local authorities and communities to develop inclusive environments for people to be active whether walking, cycling or wheeling.Kevin Lafferty, Chief Executive Office at Paths for All, said: ldquoIniduals like Ian highlight the very reason why we host an annual awards ceremony. It is vital that we celebrate and shed light on the outstanding work that volunteers carry out in local communities across Scotland on a daily basis..removeldquoOur volunteerrsquos invaluable contribution is directly working to improve the nationrsquos physical, mental and social health which has been evident throughout the pandemic, with many going above and beyond their normal duties.ldquoHearing the inspirational stories during the award ceremony has highlighted that it is not just enough to say thank you ndash the work undertaken has provided a le line for many and for that wersquore forever grateful.To find out more which Health Walks you can join in the Scottish Borders, visit: www.pathsforall.org.uk healthwalkfinder

title: borders-recorded-100-coronavirus-cases-weekend
story: THE Borders has seen a rise in cases of coronavirusover the weekend, new data shows.Updated figures were published by the Scottish Government at pm today .And the new data shows that the region saw  cases over the weekend, taking the total since the start of the pandemic to ,.:Drop-in centres to offer hot food to Borderers without power, says councilThere are currently  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of COVID-, according to the figures.On Friday, there were  people in hospital.Scotland has now recorded , cases since March last year.

title: 78-year-old-man-completes-final-fundraiser-charity
story: A -year-old Bordersrsquo man who walked almost , miles during lockdown to raise money for Cancer Research UK has finally called time on his fundraising activities after raising an impressive pound, for Cancer Research UK in memory of many of his friends who have died from the disease since the start of the pandemic.David Laing from Kelso had  falls, luckily none too serious resulting in only a few head stitches, cuts and abrasions during his travels and the wrong footwear resulted in the loss of his left foot big toe nail which still causes him pain but is starting to grow back.He was soaked many times, battered by hailstones, snow and sleet and heavy winds and had to replace four pairs of trainers but on the brighter side he has taken more than  photos of wildflowers and have named almost all, photographed some beautul scenery, river and farm le, shed a few pounds and lted litter which he have done for almost  years.He is an inspirational figure in the community who is also a telephone kindness volunteer with the Chest Heart and Stroke Association and still collates PVGs for Scottish Borders Disability Sport Group.David told the Border : ldquoOn the th November  the fund was closed after just over three months having raised the maximum amount of pound which has now all been paid over to CRUK either directly from the link or on a week to week banking arrangement.ldquoWhat a fabulous amount so thanks to all donor and supporters This is my final ever major fundraiser which I can imagine will be a huge relief to many who became lsquototally voluntaryrsquo donors without any pressure .

title: michael-buble-visit-borders-2022-summer-tour
story: GRAMMY Award-winning singer Michael Bubleacute is set to visit the Borders next year as part of his UK summer tour.Bubleacute will perform at Floors Castle in Kelso on Monday, July , .An Evening with Michael Bubleacute will see the Canadian singer tour picturesque locations across the UK for the series of open-air events.The four-time Grammy Award winner has sold more than  million records worldwide and recently released a music video for Its Beginning to Look a Lot Like Christmasahead of the th anniversary of his festive album, Christmas.Following his show in Kelso, Bubleacute will go on to perform in Durham, Bath, Cardf and Exeter.Tickets for the event at Floors Castle will go on sale on Fridayand are available at: www.aegpresents events detail michael-bubleTickets for all other dates in July  are available now.You might also be interested in:Man, , diesafter getting into dficulty in River TweedSP Energy Networks issues updateas homes still without power after Storm ArwenConcerns raised over ongoing issuesat Borders site used by travellers

title: souters-appear-holiday-alley-web-tv
story: NINE Scottish country dancers from Selkirk have appeared on a lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that aired on Holiday Alley web-TV today As part of the Holiday Alley Festival held in the town of Selkirk Manitoba, Canada, residents of towns named Selkirk from around the world were invited to film themselves dancing.The Souters, who are all aged over  took up the challenge and their dance to the -bar reel lsquoDeil Amang the Tailorsrsquo impressed the judges.Margaret Pritchard told the Border : ldquoWe are all from the Selkirk Scottish Country Dance class and have been dancing together for a long time. We got permission to film our dance in front of the Mungo Park Court which was appropriate as itrsquos just across from the statue of Mungo Park.ldquoThe dance was filmed and sent away to the festival organisers and we just received an email back saying that they were delighted with it so we are all thrilled and looking forward to watching it later this month.The women who took part were Maureen Buckley, Shirley Brown, Freda Nicholson, Margaret Pritchard, Mary Harkness, Maureen Davidson, Olive Stillie, Wendy Boustead and Ros Roxburgh.

title: power-issue-sees-borders-high-school-pupils-sent-home
story: PUPILS at a Borders high school have been sent home due to a ldquopower issue, according to the council.The local authority issued an update on the issues in the region after Storm Arwen hit the UK on the weekend.The council says that all schools ing from holiday today reopened as normal with the exception of Berwickshire High School, where a power issue has resulted in pupils being sent home.Inspections will continue today at settings in the Eyemouth and Earlston clusters to ensure they are ready for theof pupils and staff tomorrow, according to a council spokesperson.:Man, , dies after getting into dficulty in River TweedMeanwhile, Scottish Borders Council is running a drop-in centre for those still without power at Duns Primary School.The facility will be available until pm tonight .On the situation in the region, the spokesperson said: ldquoWhile supplies have been restored to a number of homes across the region, there are still those without power, mainly across rural Berwickshire.ldquoThe council continues to liaise closely with Scottish Power Energy Networks and other key partners to progress the recovery effort.ldquoAnyone who is in need of assistance should contact    up to pm. After pm the out of hours emergency number   should be used.ldquoFood and hot drinks can be provided via the Community Assistance Hubs who are able to arrange for these to be delivered. This support can be accessed by calling   .

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly Covid update to Parliament this week, just over -hours after hosting a media briefing on the new Omicron iant.So far nine cases of the Omicron iant, which was originally identied in South Africa, have been detected in Scotland.In yesterdays briefing, the first minister urged Scots to up compliance with the current Covid regulations - mask wearing, lateral flow testing, getting vaccinated, keeping rooms ventilated and maintaining high levels of hygiene.She did not introduce any new restrictions during thespeech, but warned that the government would continue to monitor the situation as we learned more about the new iant.Today the first minister stood up in front of MSPs to deliver an update on the current Covid situation in Scotland and said she "hoped" further restrictions would not be required.However, this depends on how the Omicron situation develops, with scientists racing to understand more about the iant over the coming days and weeks.Heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update in Parliament today.... All  cases of Omicron identied in Scotland linked to one eventAll nine of the current identied cases are linked to one single private event, which means that community transmission of the Omicron iant may not be too widespread.None of the people who have tested positive for Omicronin Scotland have so far required hospital tretament.. Looking at COP as source but seems unlikely cases emerged thereThe first minister confirmed Public Health Scotland was looking at COP due to the nature of the event, however said it seems highly unlikely any cases of Omicron emerged there, due to the fact it concluded over -weeks ago..   -year-olds can book second vaccines from today-year-olds in Scotland can book their second vaccines from today, following advice from the JCVI.. Situation in Scotland remains stable.removeDaily case rates continue to hover around ,, with , new cases reported today.A further  deaths were recorded, while  people were in hospital with Covid over past -hours and  in intensive care.. Average number of new cases fallen in past weekOver the past week, the average number of new cases has fallen in Scotland.Part of this is likely to be due to the booster vaccine, however the number of cases has fallen in all age groups, which the first minister described as "encouraging".She highlighted the success of the vaccine scheme and the likely links between the jabs and the reduction in case rates.. Lateral flow test to become available in more locationsLateral flow tests are to become available in many more locations in the run up to the festive season, including garden centres, sport centres and Christmas markets.Lateral flow tests are now easier to use, requiring only a nasal swap rather than a throat and nasal swab.

title: storm-arwen-borders-road-closures-outlined-council
story: A NUMBER of roads remain closed after Storm Arwen hit the Borders this weekend.Thousands of the regionrsquos residents have spent nights without powerfollowing damage caused by the weather.And Scottish Borders Council has confirmed that a number of routes are still affected.BerwickshireB - Charterhall - likely to remain closed for rest of weekB - Ayton to Eyemouth - likely to remain closed for rest of weekD  - Westloch Road, Coldingham - likely to remain closed for rest of weekC - Edrom to Blanerne - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEyemouth - High Street - buildings issueEyemouth - Victoria Road - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEyemouth - Paxton Terrace - buildings issueEyemouth - Albert Road - buildings issueOff B - Whitfield cottages - likely to remain closed for rest of weekCheviotB - Fans Farm Yarlside - likely to remain closed for rest of weekEildonD  - Ashiesteel to Craigmyle - likely to remain closed for rest of weekTweeddaleC - Tweedsmuir to Talla - likely to remain closed for rest of weekOn the closures, a council spokesperson said: ldquoSome other very minor routes may also be affected.ldquoPlease continue to drive with caution as even where trees have been cleared, there may be debris on next to the road.

title: msp-urges-bus-company-return-x95-service-hourly
story: SOUTH OF Scotland MPS Colin Symth has stepped up calls to reverse cuts to the X bus service which runs from Edinburgh to Carlisle servicing communities across Midlothian, the Borders, Dumfries and Galloway and Cumbria including Newtongrange, Hawick Galashiels and Langholm.The service now runs every two hour and Borders Buses say they have no current plans to reintroduce an hourly service due to a shortage of drivers across the country which they blame on lsquounprecedented delays in processing vocational driver licence applicationsrsquo.Sharon Morrison, communications director for Borders Buses, said: ldquoIn normal circumstances we have always responded positively to demand and requests for increased frequencies and journeys. Unfortunately, due to a driver and labour shortage across the industry and country respectively, we are unable to increase the frequency of our operation. We hope this changes over the coming months.ldquoWhilst the volumes of people travelling is down roughly % from  patronage levels, we welcome the continued support from the Scottish Government. Despite this much needed funding, the impact of Brexit, C, self-isolating and - most importantly - the unprecedented delays in processing vocational driver licence applications, continues to have a massive bearing on our service delivery.ldquoWe would also stress, unlike some operators across the UK, we are not cutting services and are operating all services registered. The is a huge testament to the hard work and effort of our Borders Buses team.Mr Smyth agreed about the backlog but also believes that the Scottish Government should have secured meaningful guarantees from bus firms that they would maintain services infor the pound.m of support given to companies during the pandemic.He said: ldquoThe UK Government need to do more by tackling the shocking backlog in processing driving licences and increasing availability of tests to ensure that when bus companies do decide to increase services they have the drivers to do so..removeldquoEveryone understands why companies reduced services when Covid hit, especially given the potential health impact on both passengers and drivers. It may also be some time before passenger numbers rise back to even close to pre-pandemic levels, but we will never get people back on our buseswe take those buses away.ldquoThe X is a crucial service that covers many communities across the South of Scotland and the lack of frequency simply means itrsquos just not an option anymore for people who want to use the bus.ldquoI have urged Borders Buses to reinstate this service to an hourly one. However, their decision not to so far highlights the failure of the Scottish Government to secure proper guarantees from bus firms that infor the tens of millions of pounds that was given to the sector during the pandemic, they should not be cutting services and we need to look again at how that support works.

title: jedburgh-pupils-waving-sanitary-products-like-flags-meeting-hears
story: BORDERS pupils using gender-neutral toilets have been ldquowaving sanitary products about like flags and urinating in sanitary bins, according to an elected official.As well as the reports of the incidents at Jedburgh Grammar School, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott says he has heard stories of girls at Kelso High School going an entire day without a toilet visit after refusing to use the unisex loos.But a Scottish Borders Councilspokesperson says that both schools have ldquono knowledge of these incidents taking place.A motion was put forward by Mr Scott at a full council meeting last week demanding the council to consult with pupils and teachers over plans to install gender-neutral toilets at the new Galashiels Academy and Peebles High buildings.:Storm Arwen: lsquoFurther strong winds expectedrsquo over next  hours, says councilAt Thursdayrsquos meeting, the independent representative said: ldquoYoung girls going through certain changes in their le are entitled to extra privacy as far as toilet facilities are concerned.ldquoThey should not have to share with teenage boys or men.On the alleged issues at the schools in Jedburgh and Kelso, Mr Scott added: ldquoThese young people need to feel safe and comfortable in their surroundings, and to be able to use the facilities on offer without embarrassment or anxiety, whether caused intentionally or otherwise.ldquoWhile Irsquom fully in agreement about providing support for minority groups, that support should be provided without the detriment to others.ldquoWhy is it not possible to have male, female and gender-neutral toilets which would cater for the needs of everyone Mr Scott called for a full consultation on the matter and for the council to publish the results.:Gamekeeper recklessly killed  protected birds on Borders estate, court hearsHe also advised discussions with the parents of primary school children due to attend the new campuses in the coming years..removeSeconding Mr Scottrsquos motion, independent Selkirkshire councillor Caroline Cochrane backed his calls for a consultation.ldquoIf wersquore saying that they [the pupils] are mature enough to share toilet facilities then they are mature enough to decide what they find acceptable and are comfortable with, she said.There has been much debate on the pros and cons of gender-neutral toilets.Those in favour of the unisex facilities say that they can help reduce bullying, as well as being more inclusive to the trans community and to disabled people with carers of the opposite sex.However, those against the loos say that they threaten the safety of women.

title: bench-memory-selkirk-singer-unveiled-home-town
story: DOZENS of people turned out to the unveiling of a commemorative bench in memory ofFrightened Rabbit frontman, Scott Hutchison in the grounds of Haining House on Saturday, November .The former stately home which was given over to the public to be used as an arts centre was chosen as the perfect location for the beautully crafted oak bench which has the words ldquoWhile Im alive, Irsquoll make tiny changes to the earth emblazoned across the front.These words were taken from the lyrics of Scotts song lsquoHead Rolls OffrsquoScott took his own le in May  after suffering from depression and a charity in his name was launched to raise awareness about children and young peoplersquos mental health issues.The bench was made by three trainee female carpenters, and was crowdfunded by fans with money left over from another bench that was situated in Kelvingrove Park in .Ade Cartwright, the organizer of the bench fundraiser, said in a statement: ldquoThis bench is for all those out there who have been touched by Scottrsquos lyrics and music, his humour and humanity. Itrsquos a place to put the headphones on and listen to his music and take a deep breath of fresh air, a place to sit down and have a good catch-up with friends, a place to celebrate Scottrsquos le and what he means to all of us. Also to just rest your weary legs, itrsquos a fair trek!To donate to the charity, visit https:tinychanges

title: voters-go-polls-old-bexley-sidcup-by-election
story: Voters are going to the polls in the Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election, with the Conservatives hoping to hold on to the seat following a turbulent period for the Government which has been peppered with allegations of sleaze.A new MP will be elected following the death of former Cabinet minister James Brokenshire in October.The seat has been contested by Louie French for the Tories and Daniel Francis for Labour, as well as Simone Reynolds for the Lib Dems, Jonathan Rooks for the Greens, and Richard Tice for the Reform Party.As the constituency has been held by the Conservatives since its inception in , and also in its ious guises since the s, Mr French will be seen as the favourite to win the contest.Boris Johnson previously rejected suggestions that allegations of sleaze being levelled at his party could be reflected at the ballot box in the by-election.vw,vw,px, px"Prime Minister Boris Johnson has visited Sidcup During a visit to Sidcup last month, he was insistent that the strength of the Toriesrsquo local candidate meant voters would back the party in the race.Mr French, a councillor of eight years, served as deputy leader of Bexley council from  to .Following his selection, he said: ldquoJames Brokenshire was a friend and mentor to me and itrsquos an honour to have been selected as the Conservative candidate for Old Bexley and Sidcup, where I hope to carry on his excellent work.ldquoI will campaign to ensure that outer London areas like Old Bexley and Sidcup are not forgotten or left behind by the mayor of London and City Hall.ldquoAnd I will work to improve access to GPs and healthcare services, building directly on Jamesrsquo work with Queen Maryrsquos Hospital, so residents can get a face-to-face GP appointment at a time that suits them.Mr Francis is also a councillor and formerly led the Labour group on Bexley council.In a message on Twitter, he said he had lived in the area for  years and vowed to work ldquotirelessly for the communityelected..removeOld Bexley  Sidcup residents are being taken for granted ndash thatrsquos why lelong Conservatives like Bob are choosing to vote Labour.Letrsquos send them a message and vote for me, Daniel Francis, tomorrow. # pic xBpCJHeGEMmdash Daniel FrancisDecember , On the Labour Party website, he wrote: ldquoI will make sure our communities are safer by reducing speeding on our main roads, tackling anti-social behaviour and putting more police on our streets.ldquoI will revitalise our high streets by standing up to Conservatives cuts and supporting Labourrsquos call to scrap business rates.ldquoAnd I will push for the increase in investment our area needs, at every level of government.ldquoSo on December , letrsquos use this one-off opportunity to send the Conservatives a message. Letrsquos tell them wersquoll no longer be taken for granted.Mr Tice, who is former chairman of the Brexit Party, announced his candidacy in a bid to send Boris Johnson a ldquopowerful message about the impact of his Governmentrsquos policies after the Conservative administration raised the tax burden to the highest level since the s.The leader of the Reform Party ndash formerly known as the Brexit Party ndash said he would be standing on a ticket of low taxes and pledged to campaign for a referendum on the target of achieving net zero carbon emissions by .Describing the seat as ldquotraditionally Conservative, the former MEP said: ldquoVoters here did not expect the Prime Minister to deliver Consocialism, a highly taxed, highly regulated nanny state.Conservative MP Mr Brokenshire, , died from lung cancer last month, with tributes paid from across the political spectrum.He represented Old Bexley and Sidcup from , having been initially elected as the MP for Hornchurch in .Mr Brokenshire won the south-east London seat with a majority of almost , at the  general election.Other candidates competing for the seat include Elaine Cheeseman for the English Democrats, Richard Hewison for Rejoin EU, David Kurten for the Heritage Party, John Poynton for Ukip, Carol Valinejad for the Christian Peoples Alliance, and Mad Mike Young for the Official Monster Raving Loony Party.The Conservatives will face a second by-election this month in North Shropshire following the resignation of Owen Paterson, whose case sparked the recent row on parliamentary standards..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Voters go to the polls in Old Bexley and Sidcup by-election

title: ministry-defence-sets-target-doubling-female-recruits-2030
story: The Ministry of Defencewill aim to more than double its number of female recruits as part of a series of changes following a report into the bullying and harassment of women in the armed services.More than , women gave evidence to the Defence Sub-Committee on Women in the Armed Forces for its landmark inquiry, which found that % of female veterans and % of serving women reported experiencing bullying, harassment and discriminationduring their careers.In its response to the report, published on Thursday, the Government said the inquiry ldquomade clear that on too many occasions Defence has failed to provide women with the experience they deserve.The MoD unveiled a number of reforms aimed at addressing the issues highlighted in the report, including an ambition to increase female inflow by % by .vw,vw,px, px"Veteran Sarah Atherton chairs the Defence Sub-Committee on Women in the Armed Forces It also said the Chain of Command would be entirely removed from complaints of a sexual nature, after a large number of surveyed women said their experiences of the complaints system were ldquoextremely poor, with complaints often being ldquobrushed under the carpet.Further adopted recommendations include a review into stronger ways of removing those who are found to have committed sexual offences, and greater independence in the system for the handling of BHD complaints.However, the MoD said it did not accept a recommendation to move cases of rape and sexual assault from military courts to the civilian system.According to the sub-committee, conviction rates in military courts are four to six times lower than in civilian courts.Sarah Atherton, chairwoman of the sub-committee and an Army veteran, thanked the MoD for its ldquothorough response.She said: ldquoThere is much more work to do, but it is clear that improving the experiences of women in the Armed Forces is becoming a priority for the Ministry of Defence. I would like to thank the Secretary of State for Defence, Ben Wallace, for his ongoing commitment to servicewomen and veterans..removeldquoOur inquiry discovered that six out of ten women who had experienced abuse, did not complain for fear of the impact it would have on their career, or because they thought nothing would be done.ldquoThe fact that a servicewoman can now make a sexual complaint safe in the knowledge that her direct Chain of Command wonrsquot be handling it is a huge step forward.ldquoThere is also set to be a more robust process for handling complaints of Bullying, Harassment and Discrimination ndash although questions remain over what this means in practice. I hope that this is the beginning of a new era of accountability for the military.However, she called the MoDrsquos decision to dismiss the sub-committeersquos recommendation on military courts ldquodisappointing, adding there was ldquoclear evidence that the current system is failing to deliver justice..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Ministry of Defence sets target of doubling female recruits by
